newsitem.title: UKRAINE: Kuchma seeks tax breaks if investors boost output.
newsitem.headline: Kuchma seeks tax breaks if investors boost output.

text.p: Ukraine's President Leonid Kuchma signed a law revoking foreign investors' tax breaks, but asked parliament to suggest a new law on breaks to businesses in the production sector, Kuchma's press service said on Thursday.

"The president stresses the need to bring in foreign investors to support our producers. Thus the chief of the nation has evaluated this law to tax businesses in the production sector and found it unacceptable," the service said.
The law, which met protest from foreign investors when parliament passed it two months ago, will scrap breaks on taxes and customs fees to joint ventures from July 1.
It also repeals tax-free status on profits earned by joint ventures before January 1, 1995.
Ukraine, which has won just $1.4 billion investment since independence in 1991, expects to receive up to $1 billion in foreign investment this year.
Foreign investors have complained of deterrents like high taxes, inconsistent laws and demands for bribes from all levels of government officials.

Ukraine is in the process of passing a series of nine tax laws to underpin the months-late 1997 budget, whose passage is expected to clear the way for a $2.5 to $3 billion, three-year credit from the International Monetary Fund.
